content:
You mention just installed Thunderbird.

Please check the Firewall on your computer. Access Firewall - this will be either the default that came with computer or it might be controlled by the Anti-Virus program you install.

Thunderbird needs to be set up as an allowed program otherwise it might get blocked. So make sure this is done. As an example: I'm using Norton 360, I've included an image below which shows how I've set up the Firewall to allow both the thunderbird exec file and the updater exec file.

Typically, the "Send" button will be grayed out if you are in 'offline' mode as described by Matt. You should see ((o)) if online.

But it will also be greyed out until a valid email address has been entered in a TO field and a pill created (press enter)

You mention : The TO: address appears in a red block with white letters. If you are using Addons & Themes > Themes: System Theme Then the red background may be part of something you selected on your computer. In the main view above the Folder Pane, locate the button called 'New Message' Does that button also have a red background with white font ? If yes, do not worry about it being red, it's a setting you have set up on computer. But we need to know to be certain, so please report back.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
Have you installed any addon extensions ? If yes: What addons have you installed ?

Please test the following: Help > Troubleshoot Mode Clickon Restart and then select 'Continue in Troubleshoot mode'

If Send is now enabled when you have entered a valid email address in the TO field then you need to see which addon is likely to causing the issue. You may need to reinstall addon, but it may be a problem you need to report to the author of the addon extension.
creator: Toad-Hall

content: See password support article
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
Do you mean you have recently accessed the webmail account and modified your passwords and therefore want to edit the stored passwords in Thunderbird ?

If yes: The password support article will help but it's not up to date and is missing the latest changes.

  • Settings > Privacy & Security
  • Scroll down to 'Passwords' section
  • Click on 'Saved Passwords'
  • Click on 'Show Passwords'

At this point you may get asked for a password. This will be one of two options: 1. If you have selected the checkbox 'Use a Primary Password' Then previously you must have set up a special 'primary password', You will be asked to enter that 'Primary Password' to get access to stored passwords. This is not a mail account password, it's something completely separate which you would have set up. If you really cannot remember that 'Primary Password' - then you have no option but to remove it entirely. This means all stored passwords for all your mail accounts will automatically be deleted.

How to remove the 'Primary PAssword':

  • https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/protect-your-thunderbird-passwords-primary-password#w_reset-your-primary-password-if-you-have-forgotten-it

Then restart Thunderbird. The 'Primary Password' should now no longer exist. At the prompt, enter the new imap mail account password. Select the checkbox to 'Remember Password' and then click on 'Ok'


2. IF you have NOT selected the checkbox 'Use a Primary Password': then you will see a 'Windows Security' small window and it wants the computer user account password...When you start up computer, the first thing it asks for is a password to get access to your User Account or Microsoft account - that is the password it wants.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
It is your Anti-Virus program. But it has nothing to do with virus. We have seen a few of these cases recently. Sounds like Anti-Virus got updated and now fails to recognises something it has been perfectly ok with previously. Most of them use self signed certificates and those cause issues with not being recognized.

If clicking on 'Bekraeft sikkerhedsundtagelse' (Confirm Security Exception') does not fix then... I would suggest you uninstall Anti-Virus Test sending to see if all is ok. If all works then you know it's the Anti-Virus Program. Then reinstall the Anti- Virus program and hopefully it will be able to read data correctly.

But please tell me...What Anti-Virus program are you using? Is it Norton ?

Second error says this in English: - using google translate Sending the message failed. Could not communicate securely with peer: the requested domain name does not match the server's certificate. Problems with the co-configuration need to be resolved

content:
Sounds like you either have not set up authentication in SMTP OR maybe you have more than one account and the account is not using it's own correct smtp.

  • In Account Settings
  • Left Pane - scroll to the bottom
  • click on 'Outgoing Server (SMTP)'

You should see a list of outgoing smtp servers.

  • Select each in turn to locate the one which has 'username' = problem account email address.
  • Click on 'Edit'
  • Description: Type the full email address = username email address.

Doing this helps to make sure you have the account using correct outgoing smtp and it will be easier to see in the next step.

  • Click on OK

Now to check account is using correct smtp:

  • In Left Pane select the name of the problem account
  • Look bottom right for the outgoing server smtp it is using...

Does it show the same email address as the mail account you selected ? IF no:

  • Click on the drop down chevron to see other options and select the one with email address that matches the account.

DO NOT click on 'Edit SMTP_Server' button at this point because first we have to establish the correct server has been selected.

creator: k.aschke

content:
Unfortunately, Anti-Virus programs are not useful when it comes to email. If Anti-virus is allowed to scan etc anything in your profile folders it has a problem because it does not undrestand how emails are stored.

Emails are downloaded to Inbox and stored in a single mbox text file called 'Inbox' (no extension). Each email is written to that file, one after the other as they are downloaded. So, one single text file document may contain a lot of emails. Anti-Virus does not know this. If it finds one email has an attachment it does not like, then if you have the setting to auto fix or you allow the fix then it's likely the entire file will get 'fixed' and this will result in email loss.

This is one of the reasons why you should create several Folders in Thunderbird to organise and store emails, so they are not all in one file. I would also advise that you do not allow any Anti-Virus or malware product access to your profile name folders OR if you do, then never allow/permit a fix, just make a note of where the problem is located. Please note: sometimes the bad file was already deleted, but not completely removed from profile - if you compact all folders then that will clean up and remove hidden marked as deleted old mail. Sometimes this in itself sotrs out the problem. Otherwise, if you know which file had problem, you can create a folder on desktop and then export copies of all emails in say the Inbox to that new folder on desktop as .eml files. Then run scan of that desktop folder. If it locates a bad email, then you know which one to delete in the Inbox in Thunderbird. Finally, delete the fodler on desktop and empty the computer recycle bin. A Bit long winded but you find the issue and don't lose emails.

However...you need to try and restore emails...I'll post in a another email/comment.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
re : I have got an system backup of the October 24, 2024

But did that backup actually backup your Thunderbird Profile ? Can we first fully establish you have a backup of the profile.

If you are using Windows OS and you have your Thunderbird profiles in the default location then you are looking for this in the backup:

  • C://Users/<username>/Appdata/Roaming/Thunderbird

That 'Thunderbird' folder should contain the following:

  • C://Users/<username>/Appdata/Roaming/Thunderbird/Profiles/<profile name>/Mail/<pop mail account name>

re :two e-mail addresses with this problem and five e-mail addresses without any problems In the 'Mail' folder, it should contain all your pop mail accounts and also 'Local Folders'.

Please confirm that you do have this backup and you can see various pop mail accounts in the Mail folder.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
IF you can confirm a good backup copy then you have a choice on how to proceed.

1. Option to do it manually You could copy and paste the relevant pop mail account name folder from the backup into the current profile. This is quick and really you are completely recovering an entire pop account. So if you only want to recover one specific file then there are other ways. But you can copy paste eg: a pop account Inbox mbox file - just make sure you are copy/pasting into the correct pop account folder. This method is done in the profile folders, so Thunderbird must be closed before you do this.

How to achieve this:

  • Exit Thunderbird now.
  • Access the backup profile ...you need to be looking at the contents of the 'Mail' folder as described in previous comment.

Then Access the current profile:

  • In windows search type: %Appdata% - see image below as guide
  • select the Appdata file folder option
  • Select 'Roaming' folder
  • Select 'Thunderbird' folder
  • select 'Profiles' folder
  • select the profile name folder
  • Select 'Mail' folder

you are now looking at your list of pop mail account name folders in the current profile. Two of those pop account folders have a problem. Only you know which ones they are. If you are unsure...in the pop account folder there will be an Inbox file no extension - open it using Notepad++ and you should be able to see contents and there might be an email address helping you id that account.

You can now look in the backup 'Mail' folder and Copy the relevant backup pop mail account folder and paste it into the current profile 'Mail' folder and let it overwrite the original OR just delete the original and paste in the copy.

Do this for both of the problem pop mail accounts.

2. The Alternative is to use an addon: This method in done within Thunderbird whilst it is running. Addon extension called 'ImportExportTools NG'

  • https://addons.thunderbird.net/en-us/thunderbird/addon/importexporttools-ng/

How to install addon:

  • https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/installing-addon-thunderbird

This tool will allow you to import a mbox file from a backup or an Inbox plus any subfolders it contains Or all mbox files in a directory. In Thunderbird Folder Pane Right click on pop mail account name and select: ImportExportTools NG > Import mbox files > then choose the best option.....note....folders with .sbd extension means they contain subfolders and their emails. Then locate the backup pop mail account and depending upon what option you chose either select the pop mail account folder or select the required mbox file and clickon Open to import.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
Informazioni utili da fornire nelle richieste di supporto:

  1. Versione di Thunderbird
  2. Versione del sistema operativo
  3. Provider delle caselle email (Gmail, Libero, Hotmail, etc.)
  4. Tipologia di account (POP3, IMAP)
  5. Estensioni installate
  6. Messaggi di errore che vengono visualizzati durante l'utilizzo di Thunderbird
  7. Software di sicurezza eventualmente presenti (Antivirus e simili)

content:
• Come hai eliminato l'account?
  • Hai eliminato anche il server SMTP? (Tasto menu > Impostazioni account> Server in uscita SMTP)
  • Usavi anche le funzioni Calendario di Gmail? Se si, hai eliminato il relativo account?
  • Similmente usavi anche la chat di Gmail?

Se invece vuoi ripartire da zero, la semplice disinstallazione non basta. Puoi fare due cose: - Disinstallare e poi cancellare la cartella del profilo -> https://support.mozilla.org/it/kb/profili-thunderbird#w_come-trovare-il-proprio-profilo Quindi reinstallare Thunderbird - Creare un nuovo profilo -> https://support.mozilla.org/it/kb/utilizzare-piu-profili che andrà ad affiancare quello esistente. In questo modo puoi ripartire da zero e rimuovere il vecchio profilo solo quando sei certo che quello nuovo funziona correttamente.
creator: @next

content: Ho eliminato l'account dalle impostazioni dell'app ("elimina account"). L'unico server SMTP che ho nell'app è quello dell'account che continuo a usare. Usavo anche le funzionalità di Google Calendar, non pensavo che si trattasse di un account diverso da quello di posta. Non so se riesco a raggiungerlo, poiché ci arrivavo solo tramite l'account email. Non vorrei ripartire da zero, perché l'ho già fatto più volte; se esistesse un'altra via, sarei sollevato. Se non vi fosse altra soluzione, proverei a rimuovere la cartella del profilo. Grazie.

content:
Thunderbird does not have a scam folder, it has a junk/spam folder the name being dependent of the server the account is attached to.

Certain antivirus products have traditionally installed components into Thunderbird without asking. Those components usually go belly up what a new version is installed, so could it be your antivirus that is the problem here.
